div.p: Greetings. I have just now received your letters along with those of our Calvin, in which you wish to be informed about what Gwalther and I intend to do with the French book sent to us, which you desire to be translated into our language and printed.
However, that Michael Cunerus, otherwise an excellent man, was delayed on his journey due to physical weakness; therefore, only in these recent days did he deliver the book to us.
Master Georg Cellarius has received it and will attempt to translate it; we have spoken with Froschauer, who has not shown himself to be difficult, provided it is translated in a timely manner.
I am pressing on; for you know that only a few days remain until the fair, during which the printers can print.
This matter is dear to us, and nothing will be lacking in our diligence.
I have somewhat recovered; but numbness of the limbs occupies my body, and I feel perpetual pains in both my head and stomach.
May the Lord do what is good in His eyes!

Zürich, Bern, and Schaffhausen are indignant that Sulcerus and Coccius subscribed to the Confession and Apology of Augsburg in the Strasbourg agreement; for now, there is a rumor that the people of Basel have separated themselves from the other Swiss cities and have accepted Luther's doctrine in the supper.

The cities have consulted on this matter; during the consultation, Sulcerus came to Bern; summoned to the council and asked what he had done in Strasbourg, he replied that the acts are contained in a deposition with the council in Basel.

Therefore, a letter was sent to Basel requesting the acts; the people of Basel responded that they have no acts and have only heard a report from Sulcerus about the settlement of the predestination dispute.
The cities, since they know for certain that he subscribed, are consulting further on what needs to be done.
Whatever happens, I will write at the earliest opportunity.
Sulcerus is an excellent equivocator; it is said that he recommends the books of Paul Eber (in which Calvin is specifically criticized) and Martin Chemnitz, etc.
I cannot write more; the courier is in haste.
May Master Calvin, Master Jonville, and all the brothers be safe.
All of ours greet you. August 8, 1563.
To the most illustrious man, Master Théodore de Bèze, the most faithful minister of the church of Geneva, most esteemed lord and dearest brother.
